instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Very small amount of liquid damage on the LCDBKLT caps (<CAPACITOR>C8469</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C8411</CAPACITOR>) and around the <CHIP>U3700</CHIP> Wifi. Stuck it in the ultrasonic cleaner and replaced the 2 caps. Still on 20v 0a.

Started trouble shoots the rails:

PPBUS - 13.10v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - fluctuating 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - fluctuating
PP5V-S5 -fluctuating

Replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> along with <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> to rule out the possibility that it was coming from a bad MOSFET. still the same

Replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> still the same. Removed L7690 and the fluctuation is coming from the system side (pin 1)

Check all the above rails and non of them are shorted to ground. Also had a prob on other rails and non of them are shorted either.

Any help of what to try next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Which kind of fluctuation?
Do you mean pulsing every 2-3s, or continue fluctuation?

Test the board alone on the desk, nothing connected, apart of USB-C charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Continuous fluctuation.

Them readings and the above explanation is on my desk with nothing connected apart from USB-C.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Post basic voltage for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>: pins 23, 22, 12, 13, 29, 21, 4.
Mention the ones with fluctuation...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Pin 4 - 0.00
Pin 12 - fluctuating between 3.42 and 0
Pin 13 - fluctuating between 2.0 and 0
Pin 21 - fluctuating between 3.42 and 0
Pin 22- 3.2
Pin 23 - 13.1
Pin 29 - fluctuating between 5.0 and 0

Fluctuations are approximate as I can't get an exact voltage figure.

Just in case you need to know none of them are shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - fluctuating
------------------
Pin 4 - 0.00"
<SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> should stay at 0V all the time.

Remove <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> and check if fluctuation disappears.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> stable then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: Removed <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> and the fluctuation is still present on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Keep <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> out and solder wire on <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR>.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> should be 0V; check if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: When you say solder wire on <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> do you mean bridge it as the cap is NOSTUFF

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0v and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is steady high with <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> bridged and <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuation may affect <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> too.
Now put back <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> and remove <CHIP>U7890</CHIP>; tied together its pads 4 & 6, on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
I've put <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> back, left <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> bridged and I only now get 5.17v 0.27a 

With the bridge removed back up to 12v 0a <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0v and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is stable at 5v.

Just in case it helps from <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> voltages:

Pin 4 - 0.00
 Pin 12 - 3.42
 Pin 13 - 2.0
 Pin 21 - 3.42
 Pin 22- 3.2
 Pin 23 - 13.1
 Pin 29 - Which mentioned above is 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
In my previous post, I forgot to mention to remove <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> bridge too.
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> comes on...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: No. With the bridge removed from <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> I get 0v on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is stable at 5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: Did what I said about <CHIP>U7890</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Yes steps so far. Put <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> back, removed <CAPACITOR>C7668</CAPACITOR> bridge and removed <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> with a bridge from pin4 to 6
 I get 0v on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is stable at 5v.

Just in case it helps from <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> voltages:

 Pin 4 - 0.00
 Pin 12 - 3.42
 Pin 13 - 2.0
 Pin 21 - 3.42
 Pin 22- 3.2
 Pin 23 - 13.1
 Pin 29 - Which mentioned above is 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Then <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> has all inputs required to generate <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
There must be broken solder/trace, or bad component on its <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> section.
Pay atention to <RESISTOR>R7684</RESISTOR>/85/86 and <CAPACITOR>C7689</CAPACITOR>.
Did you change <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> along with <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> have all been changed and have come from a working board, so I know that they are all fine.

I don't think this is a problem with <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> as my first post says 'Replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> still the same. Removed L7690 and the fluctuation is coming from the system side (pin 1)'

This problem is coming from somewhere else..

I've tried injecting 3.2v 1a into Pin1 of L7690 with it removed and my power supply is tripping on-off as if it is still fluctuating.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
A buck converter can't be tested without its coil; no output voltage in such case.

If your lab PSU fluctuates, there can be a problem indeed.
Supposing you set the amp limit to max; not tripping because amp limit is too low.
1A limit doesn't help to diagnose.

Post actual diode mode to ground at L7690.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: I was worried about putting the amp to max as it's going to the PCH and I didn't want to cause any damage to it. I suppose the schematics says that max can be is 7.33A max so I will try this and use the thermal camera.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Did you check diode mode to ground?

You can't set the injected amp; that is decided by the resistance to ground and voltage injected.
Just let amp limit to max...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Well after pumping the amps to max and using the thermal camera found the problem to be <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>!!! hidden by the shield after removing this I can clearly see 1 burnt component!!!!

Removed <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, replaced L7690 back and now I have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message: Does the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> have a firmware?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
It has firmware; not sure if paired with the board.
Best thing to do, use donor from same board model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0a [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Replaced from a donor board and all is working now

Thank you for your help
